messageBody:
I agree as well.  Unstandardized QS does not affect understandability.  So if that is the case then it should not be a problem for people to write as they speak.  I am a U.S. citizen, and in the mid 70s I corresponded with a man in New Zealand in QS.  I had no difficulty in understanding his QS.  I think the drive toward standardizing QS arises out of the same human desire for uniformity that sent TO down the wrong path centuries ago.


Paige Gabhart


On 2/21/2013 9:01 AM, moira_ob wrote:
 

I so agree with Nash. I write QS as I speak - and I read other's writing in their speech with their pronunciation. It does not detract from my understanding of what they are writing, rather it gives the right colour to their "speech".

Long live unstandardised QS.

Moira

Moira O'Brien LIPF
www.corkinternationalradio.com

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "raghaillaigh" wrote:
>
> I really like QS. I use it to write my journal.
>
> But it can either be phonetic or it can be standardized ï¿½ it cannot be both. To standardize QS is to start making the same mistake that brought modern English spelling to the state it's in. Once writing is divorced from pronunciation, then the writing is about something else. For example,the three day gathering whose name is pronounced "wickï¿½d fair" is written "Wicked Faire". Here, spelling is used to say something non-linguistic about the gathering.
>
> There is a quicker solution to the spelling problem than adopting QS: it's called "spelling pronunciation". That's where the T pronounced in "often" comes from. It's why I make a distinction between eh-ffect and ae-ffect, wailing and whaling. In other words, it is by forcing a correspondence between writing and pronunciation and turn TO into a phonetic system.
> Vin
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan wrote:

> > fern.wing169 scripsit:
> >
> > > No-- 'wh' isn't always used before why. How you write it is supposed
> > > to depend on *your* accent. British speakers would write their words
> > > differently than, say, someone from ohio. You should write the
> > > lettering the way that you phonetically pronounce it when you speak.
> >
> > Just be aware that not everyone adopts that point of view. When writing
> > for yourself only, you can do whatever you like, of course. But it's
> > clear that Read designed his script so that everyone would write the
> > same way, which is why he insists that words like START are written with
> > Are, not with Ah, even though almost everybody outside North America
> > pronounces them the same way.
> >
> > > Also, in most cases you don't have to distinguish awe from ah from
> > > "ox". Those three symbols look visually similar for a reason. It's so
> > > that when you're writing you can just sort of blur them together and
> > > people will still know how to pronounce what you wrote.
> >
> > Every English-speaker outside of North America makes a three-way
> > distinction, and about 50% of the people in the U.S. make a two-way
> > distinction: for most of us, Ox = Ah, but in Eastern New England Ox = Awe.
